narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  she is really helpful with her deep knowledge in the field.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse- she is wonderful.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse Duguid
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  MD

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Her deep knowledge in the field is strengths.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Absolutely brilliant, knows all of the trees, could teach this, and many other classes, easily on her own (although a perfect complement to Ann)

Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse is a superstar! She really knows her stuff, and has lots of great mnemonic devices for remembering how to differentiate between similar tree species, etc. She also offered review sessions and regularly emailed practice quizzes to the class.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Marlyse was great, she always answered questions and knew basically everything and anything about plants. I don't think there can be much improved.
Instructor: Marlyse Corallo Duguid  Her work as a TA was outstanding.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Only saying that the class was "average" for a student since it's so NE focused. Would love a lecture or two at the beginning explaining the big picture of taxonomy, including a variety of regions.

Ann is a fantastic professor. Her enthusiasm for the subject is boundless; she is full of knowledge and answers questions clearly; her field trips were all-around wonderful learning experiences. This is a class that could not be taught in a classroom, and we were so lucky to have Ann taking us into the forest every week.
The number of field trips was simply AMAZING. This course really got the foresters in the forests!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: getting ability to identify trees in the New England region, At the same time, the way I see the world changed after taking this class. I started looking trees carefully such as the shape of leaves, color of burkes. Even walking down the street, I started enjoying new landscapes captured with my new 'eyes'. The material covered in the class is applicable even in the different part of the world.
Ann and Marlyse are amazing, and the fiedltrips are just right.
The field trips, the diversity of sites we visited and the fact that as an international student without a car you got to see a good deal of the forests in Connecticut :)
Field trips! In particular, the field trip to Southern VT with Tom Wessels was fascinating and a highlight of my time at FES thus far.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It would be helpful if there is one or two classroom lectures that covers basic concept/hint to memorize all the scientific names
Would love 1 or 2 lectures at the beginning. Also, another review session or two would be really nice, but also asking a lot.

We definitely should have had a few classes covering the Taxonomy part (rather additional classes than cancelling field trips), since this was a big part of the final exam. Also it should have been made clearer that in the midterms exam we are supposed to know all of the species already.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Teh fieldtrips / labs are central to the class.
Well, again, we didn't really have classes. One or two lectures of 2-3h would have been really helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Connecting knowledge I've already had

While it is academically and professionally useful, it's mostly a great way to spend time outside, learn something real, and explore new areas around New Haven. All foresters should be able to identify trees!
If you are a forester you need to know your plants. It's as simple as that.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I realized the basic concept of 'taxonomy' is important in pursuing my future career - even if I would be working in the policy field. I also wanted to know more about the New England forests
Opportunity to be outside and I'm terrible at identifying trees. That was embarrassing.
I took this course as an undergraduate, hoping to get a taste of the forestry school. It inspired me so much that I want to apply for a masters in forestry after I graduate.
Frankly, because I can't feel at home without knowing the plants around me.
To gain knowledge about species in temperate North American forests.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes, although I would love a bit of a wider regional focus, maybe a lecture on the south and a lecture on the west.
YES!
Yes, definitely. I was surprised that we hardly covered any Picea or Abies species but I guess that's ok.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would recommend - Great class that enable you to learn about this New England Region with lots of field trip opportunity.
DO IT! Show up for the fieldtrips and feel lucky that we have professors and TAs who are willing to take students into the field.

Take this course if you love being outdoors and want to know your trees. Be careful to study as you go and practice on your own. Don't think of learning the tree species as memorization; think of it as making new friends. It takes time, but your memories will stick if you put in that time to form new relationships with each tree.
So this course is mostly valuable if you are going to work in a temperate region, preferably even in the US. The taxonomy part helps you orient yourself in general, though.
Do it.
